content.rendered:
From dark and moody to colorful and decorative to crisp and luxurious — or some combinations thereabouts — with work from Chihuaha, Barcelona, and London.

Alma Negra by Estudio Yeyé

Alma Negra Café (Black Soul Coffee) is a coffee shop in Mexico City with a dark arts sort of vibe emphasized by a cornucopia of cartesian, magic diagrams and other creepy-esque illustrations by Chihuahua, Mexico-based Estudio Yeyé. The best of the diagrams (not pictured) is the hours of operation graphic. The whole aesthetic is very well achieved through old clipart illustrations and a black and white palette. My favorite element is the logo in the middle cup above where the letters of the name disappear sequentially into a triangle. (Maybe they started disappearing because of the kerning on the far right “A”). Overall, I dig the dark-ish look that pairs well with the elixir that is coffee. See full project

Hidraulik by Huaman Studio

Based in Barcelona, Hidraulik designs modular rugs that look like antique tiles. The product itself is quite stunning, at least based on the pictures. The identity, designed by local firm Huaman Studio certainly helps with the overall presentation. The logo, in Circular I believe, is very simply typeset over a dashed line, an abstract of the tiles and serves as the anchor for the beautiful, minimalist packaging. To boot, if the pictures explain it correctly, the same box can adapt — telescopically — to the three different tile sizes. Huaman also got to design their own set of tiles, called the Modern series. Not a bad gig. See full project

Gripoix by Mind

Gripoix is a jewelry designer in Paris that designs gold structures encrusted with colorful glass beads in repeating patterns. This is echoed in the pattern by London-based Mind Design of a looping line with colorful spots filled in and printed on gold ink. The dense pattern is contrasted by a really pretty wordmark, a rich man’s Optima, always rendered black on white. The two distinct elements play even better together in the packaging, where outer white boxes allow a strip of the pattern to be seen or the bags that are printed with the pattern on the inside. Overall, a beautiful, luxurious look that matches the product. See full project (Via BP&O)
